components.description:
The circular symbol frequently used to represent the concepts of yin and yang (also yinyang or yin-yang).

The yin and yang symbol (or taijitu) shows a balance between two opposite but interconnected forces with a portion of the opposite element in each section.
components.title: Yin Yang

description:
The circular symbol frequently used to represent the concepts of yin and yang (also yinyang or yin-yang).

The yin and yang symbol (or taijitu) shows a balance between two opposite but interconnected forces with a portion of the opposite element in each section.
title: Yin Yang

version.description:
Unicode 1.1 were pre-dated emoji inclusion in Unicode by 17 years, and included many characters primarily sourced from the Zapf Dingbats font.

The following characters were added to Unicode in 1993 and many were given emoji presentation status in the years 2010-2015.

emoji_net_data.category: Miscellaneous Symbols -> Religious and political symbols
emoji_net_data.definition: Yin Yang was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015. Copy and paste this emoji: Copy http://emojipedia.org/yin-yang/
emoji_net_data.name: yin yang

bn:00008043n: A state in which opposing forces harmonise; equilibrium
The amount of economic resource required to bring opposite economic resource flows to a state of equilibrium.

bn:00655124n: In Chinese philosophy, yin & yang, which are often shortened to "yin-yang" or "yin yang", are concepts used to describe how apparently opposite or contrary forces are actually complementary, interconnected, and interdependent in the natural world, and how they give rise to each other as they interrelate to one another.
